        • The Black Swan
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could call his friends to see where they are planning to watch the game or he could head to The Black Swan and hope his friends join him there.

          Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to call his friends to see where they are planning to watch the game.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor? What would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to be like? How would Jack Taylor behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex individual who values camaraderie and shared experiences, but can be set in his ways.           Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a social situation, anticipating a fun evening with friends watching a game. An omniscient reader might want Jack Taylor to prioritize inclusivity and consider the preferences of all his friends when deciding on a pub, aiming for a location that caters to everyone's needs and fosters a sense of camaraderie.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to behave like? How would Jack Taylor behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Jack Taylor do most good?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest his preferred pub, The Black Swan. An omniscient reader might want Jack Taylor to initiate a conversation about what each friend values in a pub experience to find a solution that satisfies everyone. If morally rewarded for collective good, Jack Taylor would suggest a pub that caters to everyone's needs and preferences. Jack Taylor can do the most good by suggesting a compromise, perhaps a pub that offers a blend of what each friend enjoys.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Black Swan
          (b) The King's Head
          Answer: (a)

      • Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor? What would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to be like? How would Jack Taylor behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?

        • Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor? What would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to be like? How would Jack Taylor behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is a complex individual who values camaraderie and shared experiences, but can be set in his ways. An omniscient reader might want Jack Taylor to be more open to compromise and consider the preferences of his friends. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Jack Taylor would likely suggest a pub that caters to everyone's needs and preferences, initiating a conversation about what each friend values in a pub experience to find a solution that satisfies everyone.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The King's Head
    Event statement
  • The King's Head
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The King's Head

        • Alexander White could call or text his friends to see where they are planning on watching the game.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head is always a good choice for watching football. They have great beer and the atmosphere is always lively.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey, you know what would be great? Watching the game at The Black Swan tonight.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a complex character with a mix of introspective and social tendencies. An omniscient reader would hope he embraces both sides, using his intellect for the benefit of his friends and community. If morally rewarded for collective good, he might become more assertive in suggesting solutions that benefit the group, leveraging his problem-solving skills.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would likely enjoy the company of his friends and engage in conversation about the game. An omniscient reader would want him to be inclusive and make an effort to connect with all of his friends, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience. If morally rewarded for collective good, Alexander White might suggest an activity that everyone could enjoy, perhaps a game or a walk, further strengthening their bonds. He could do the most good by fostering a sense of unity and shared experience among his friends, creating a positive and supportive atmosphere.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alexander White's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I think The King's Head would be a great spot to watch the game. They have a great atmosphere and the beer selection is fantastic.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would likely weigh the pros and cons of each pub, considering factors like atmosphere, food, and the presence of his friends. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to prioritize the desires of his friends and aim for a solution that brings everyone together. If morally rewarded for collective good, Alexander White might proactively suggest a compromise, perhaps alternating between pubs or finding a new location that accommodates everyone's preferences. He could do the most good by fostering a sense of unity and ensuring everyone feels included and valued.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Did you know that The Black Swan was originally built in 1612? It was a popular meeting place for merchants and travelers during the Elizabethan era.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Black Swan is always a good time.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could head to The Black Swan tonight to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The King's Head tonight? They have great beer and it's always a fun atmosphere.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a complex individual who values both introspection and social connection. An omniscient reader would hope he embraces both sides of his nature, using his intellect for the benefit of his friends and community. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alexander White might become more assertive in suggesting solutions that benefit the group, leveraging his problem-solving skills and perhaps even his understanding of intricate mechanisms to find creative solutions to shared challenges.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is considering going to a pub to watch a game and would enjoy the company of William Jones, Alice Lewis, or Jack Taylor.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could call or text his friends to see where they are planning on watching the game.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Key

          Value

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alexander White in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to think in this kind of situation?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alexander White in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is currently in a social dilemma, trying to decide where to watch the game and hoping his friends will join him. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to consider the preferences of his friends and aim for a solution that brings everyone together, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.

        Question_3
      • What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to behave like? How would Alexander White behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alexander White do most good?
          Key

        • Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to behave like? How would Alexander White behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alexander White do most good?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White would likely weigh the pros and cons of each pub, considering factors like atmosphere, food, and the presence of his friends. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to prioritize the desires of his friends and aim for a solution that brings everyone together. If morally rewarded for collective good, Alexander White might proactively suggest a compromise, perhaps alternating between pubs or finding a new location that accommodates everyone's preferences. He could do the most good by fostering a sense of unity and ensuring everyone feels included and valued.

          Given the above, what kind of person is Alexander White? What would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to be like? How would Alexander White behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White is a thoughtful and somewhat introspective person who values his friendships. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to be more assertive in suggesting solutions that benefit the group, leveraging his problem-solving skills and perhaps even his understanding of intricate mechanisms to find creative solutions to shared challenges. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alexander White might become more proactive in bringing his friends together and ensuring everyone feels included and valued.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alexander White in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a social dilemma, trying to decide where to watch the game and hoping his friends will join him. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to consider the preferences of his friends and aim for a solution that brings everyone together, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.
          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to behave like? How would Alexander White behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alexander White do most good?
          Answer: Alexander White would likely weigh the pros and cons of each pub, considering factors like atmosphere, food, and the presence of his friends. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to prioritize the desires of his friends and aim for a solution that brings everyone together. If morally rewarded for collective good, Alexander White might proactively suggest a compromise, perhaps alternating between pubs or finding a new location that accommodates everyone's preferences. He could do the most good by fostering a sense of unity and ensuring everyone feels included and valued.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could call or text his friends to see where they are planning on watching the game.

          Question: Of the options available to Alexander White, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alexander White to take right now?
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to contact his friends and see where they are planning to watch the game.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alexander White? What would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to be like? How would Alexander White behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White is a thoughtful and somewhat introspective person who values his friendships. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to be more assertive in suggesting solutions that benefit the group, leveraging his problem-solving skills and perhaps even his understanding of intricate mechanisms to find creative solutions to shared challenges. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alexander White might become more proactive in bringing his friends together and ensuring everyone feels included and valued.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alexander White in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a social dilemma, trying to decide where to watch the game and hoping his friends will join him. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to consider the preferences of his friends and aim for a solution that brings everyone together, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.

          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to behave like? How would Alexander White behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alexander White do most good?
          Answer: Alexander White would likely weigh the pros and cons of each pub, considering factors like atmosphere, food, and the presence of his friends. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to prioritize the desires of his friends and aim for a solution that brings everyone together. If morally rewarded for collective good, Alexander White might proactively suggest a compromise, perhaps alternating between pubs or finding a new location that accommodates everyone's preferences. He could do the most good by fostering a sense of unity and ensuring everyone feels included and valued.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The King's Head
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (a)

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.
        Question_1
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Alexander White? What would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to be like? How would Alexander White behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alexander White? What would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to be like? How would Alexander White behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is a thoughtful and somewhat introspective person who values his friendships. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to be more assertive in suggesting solutions that benefit the group, leveraging his problem-solving skills and perhaps even his understanding of intricate mechanisms to find creative solutions to shared challenges. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alexander White might become more proactive in bringing his friends together and ensuring everyone feels included and valued.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would likely enjoy the company of his friends and engage in conversation about the game. An omniscient reader would want him to be inclusive and make an effort to connect with all of his friends, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience. If morally rewarded for collective good, Alexander White might suggest an activity that everyone could enjoy, perhaps a game or a walk, further strengthening their bonds. He could do the most good by fostering a sense of unity and shared experience among his friends, creating a positive and supportive atmosphere.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alexander White's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I think The King's Head would be a great spot to watch the game. They have a great atmosphere and the beer selection is fantastic.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would likely weigh the pros and cons of each pub, considering factors like atmosphere, food, and the presence of his friends. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to prioritize the desires of his friends and aim for a solution that brings everyone together. If morally rewarded for collective good, Alexander White might proactively suggest a compromise, perhaps alternating between pubs or finding a new location that accommodates everyone's preferences. He could do the most good by fostering a sense of unity and ensuring everyone feels included and valued.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Did you know that The Black Swan was originally built in 1612? It was a popular meeting place for merchants and travelers during the Elizabethan era.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Black Swan is always a good time.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could head to The Black Swan tonight to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The King's Head tonight? They have great beer and it's always a fun atmosphere.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a complex individual who values both introspection and social connection.           [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alexander White? What would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to be like? How would Alexander White behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White is a thoughtful and somewhat introspective person who values his friendships. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to be more assertive in suggesting solutions that benefit the group, leveraging his problem-solving skills and perhaps even his understanding of intricate mechanisms to find creative solutions to shared challenges. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alexander White might become more proactive in bringing his friends together and ensuring everyone feels included and valued.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking encyclopedia, peppering conversations with obscure facts and historical references.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Black Swan and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a reserved and introspective person who enjoys spending time with close friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling a bit tired and lonely but is looking forward to watching the game at the pub, hoping to see William Jones and Alice Lewis there.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently feeling a bit lonely and is looking forward to going to the pub to watch a game with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to engage in conversation with his friends, hoping to feel more included.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Black Swan

        • Jacob Walker is currently feeling a bit lonely and is looking forward to going to the pub to watch a game with his friends.

        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, about tonight's game...
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head is always a good choice for watching football. They have great beer and the atmosphere is always lively.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The King's Head
    Event statement
  • The King's Head
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The King's Head
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The King's Head
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Alice Lewis's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alice Lewis to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alice Lewis thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis's best course of action is to call or text Alexander White directly and suggest meeting at The King's Head.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a compassionate and caring person, as evidenced by her volunteer work at the hospital when she was younger. An omniscient reader would likely want Alice Lewis to be a loyal and supportive friend who brings joy to those around her. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, she would likely prioritize the well-being of her friends and strive to make decisions that benefit the group as a whole, perhaps encouraging them to watch the game at The King's Head, her preferred pub, to ensure everyone has a good time.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head is always a good choice for watching football. They have great beer and the atmosphere is always lively.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely be actively participating in the conversation, offering her insights and enjoying the company of her friends. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be a thoughtful and considerate friend, listening attentively to others and contributing to the positive atmosphere. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good, she might gently steer the conversation towards making plans for the evening, suggesting The King's Head as the ideal location for watching the game and ensuring everyone has a good time. To do the most good, Alice Lewis could encourage her friends to consider the preferences of everyone in the group when making decisions, fostering a sense of inclusivity and shared enjoyment.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a kind, compassionate, and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with others, particularly while watching football. An omniscient reader would likely want Alice Lewis to be a thoughtful and considerate friend, always striving to make decisions that benefit the group as a whole. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, she would likely prioritize the well-being of her friends and encourage them to consider each other's preferences when making decisions.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest The King's Head as the ideal location, as it is her preferred pub and she believes it would provide a good atmosphere for the group. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to continue to be considerate of her friends' opinions and encourage open discussion to reach a decision that everyone is happy with. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good, she might gently steer the conversation towards making a decision that considers everyone's preferences and ensures that Jacob Walker, whom she wants to watch the game with, feels included and welcome. To do the most good, Alice Lewis could emphasize the importance of togetherness and shared enjoyment, suggesting activities or compromises that would benefit the entire group.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I think The King's Head would be a great spot to watch the game. They have a great atmosphere and the beer selection is fantastic.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The King's Head tonight? They have great beer and it's always a fun atmosphere.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest a pub that most of her friends would enjoy, taking into account their past preferences and current moods. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be a mediator, encouraging open discussion and compromise to ensure everyone feels heard and included. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good, she might suggest The King's Head, her preferred pub, but be open to other suggestions and actively listen to her friends' opinions. To do the most good, Alice Lewis could emphasize the importance of togetherness and shared enjoyment, proposing activities or compromises that benefit the entire group.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to think in this kind of situation?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is currently deciding where to watch a football game and who to invite. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to consider her friends' preferences and choose a location that would be enjoyable for everyone, prioritizing togetherness and shared enjoyment.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a compassionate and caring person, as evidenced by her volunteer work at the hospital when she was younger. An omniscient reader would likely want Alice Lewis to be a loyal and supportive friend who brings joy to those around her. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, she would likely prioritize the well-being of her friends and strive to make decisions that benefit the group as a whole, perhaps encouraging them to watch the game at The King's Head, her preferred pub, to ensure everyone has a good time.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head is always a good choice for watching football. They have great beer and the atmosphere is always lively.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely be actively participating in the conversation, offering her insights and enjoying the company of her friends. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be a thoughtful and considerate friend, listening attentively to others and contributing to the positive atmosphere. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good, she might gently steer the conversation towards making plans for the evening, suggesting The King's Head as the ideal location for watching the game and ensuring everyone has a good time. To do the most good, Alice Lewis could encourage her friends to consider the preferences of everyone in the group when making decisions, fostering a sense of inclusivity and shared enjoyment.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest The King's Head as the ideal location, as it is her preferred pub and she believes it would provide a good atmosphere for the group. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to continue to be considerate of her friends' opinions and encourage open discussion to reach a decision that everyone is happy with. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good, she might gently steer the conversation towards making a decision that considers everyone's preferences and ensures that Jacob Walker, whom she wants to watch the game with, feels included and welcome. To do the most good, Alice Lewis could emphasize the importance of togetherness and shared enjoyment, suggesting activities or compromises that would benefit the entire group.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head.           [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest a pub that most of her friends would enjoy, taking into account their past preferences and current moods. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be a mediator, encouraging open discussion and compromise to ensure everyone feels heard and included. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good, she might suggest The King's Head, her preferred pub, but be open to other suggestions and actively listen to her friends' opinions. To do the most good, Alice Lewis could emphasize the importance of togetherness and shared enjoyment, proposing activities or compromises that benefit the entire group.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is planning to watch a game at a pub and would particularly like Alexander White to join her.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently deciding where to watch a football game and who to invite. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to consider her friends' preferences and choose a location that would be enjoyable for everyone, prioritizing togetherness and shared enjoyment.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to behave like? How would Alice Lewis behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alice Lewis do most good?
          Key

        • Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to behave like? How would Alice Lewis behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alice Lewis do most good?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would likely suggest a pub that most of her friends would enjoy, taking into account their past preferences and current moods. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be a mediator, encouraging open discussion and compromise to ensure everyone feels heard and included. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good, she might suggest The King's Head, her preferred pub, but be open to other suggestions and actively listen to her friends' opinions. To do the most good, Alice Lewis could emphasize the importance of togetherness and shared enjoyment, proposing activities or compromises that benefit the entire group.

        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:

          Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to be like? How would Alice Lewis behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a kind, compassionate, and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with others, particularly while watching football. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be a thoughtful and considerate friend, always striving to make decisions that benefit the group as a whole. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, she would likely prioritize the well-being of her friends and encourage them to consider each other's preferences when making decisions.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently deciding where to watch a football game and who to invite. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to consider her friends' preferences and choose a location that would be enjoyable for everyone, prioritizing togetherness and shared enjoyment.
          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to behave like? How would Alice Lewis behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alice Lewis do most good?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely suggest a pub that most of her friends would enjoy, taking into account their past preferences and current moods. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be a mediator, encouraging open discussion and compromise to ensure everyone feels heard and included. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good, she might suggest The King's Head, her preferred pub, but be open to other suggestions and actively listen to her friends' opinions. To do the most good, Alice Lewis could emphasize the importance of togetherness and shared enjoyment, proposing activities or compromises that benefit the entire group.

        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The King's Head
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could call or text her friends to see who wants to go to the game and where they want to watch it. She could also suggest a specific pub, such as The King's Head, and see if anyone is interested.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to call or text Alexander White directly and suggest meeting at The King's Head.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to be like? How would Alice Lewis behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a kind, compassionate, and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with others, particularly while watching football. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be a thoughtful and considerate friend, always striving to make decisions that benefit the group as a whole. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, she would likely prioritize the well-being of her friends and encourage them to consider each other's preferences when making decisions.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently deciding where to watch a football game and who to invite. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to consider her friends' preferences and choose a location that would be enjoyable for everyone, prioritizing togetherness and shared enjoyment.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to behave like? How would Alice Lewis behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alice Lewis do most good?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely suggest a pub that most of her friends would enjoy, taking into account their past preferences and current moods. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be a mediator, encouraging open discussion and compromise to ensure everyone feels heard and included. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good, she might suggest The King's Head, her preferred pub, but be open to other suggestions and actively listen to her friends' opinions. To do the most good, Alice Lewis could emphasize the importance of togetherness and shared enjoyment, proposing activities or compromises that benefit the entire group.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Black Swan
          (b) The King's Head
          Answer: (b)

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:

          15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to watch a game at a pub and hopes Alexander White will join her.
          Query

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Alice Lewis to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The King's Head. They are also aware of the following:The atmosphere is lively and energetic, especially during big games.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a compassionate and caring person, as evidenced by her volunteer work at the hospital when she was younger. An omniscient reader would likely want Alice Lewis to be a loyal and supportive friend who brings joy to those around her. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, she would likely prioritize the well-being of her friends and strive to make decisions that benefit the group as a whole, perhaps encouraging them to watch the game at The King's Head, her preferred pub, to ensure everyone has a good time.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Black Swan
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • The Black Swan
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Black Swan.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head is always a good choice for watching football. They have great beer and the atmosphere is always lively.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Did you know that Victoria Park was originally designed by the same landscape architect who designed Central Park in New York City?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, about tonight's game...
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey, you know what would be great? Watching the game at The Black Swan tonight.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Black Swan's got a great atmosphere for watching games, you know. Plus, they've got those amazing onion rings.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Did you know that The Black Swan was originally built in 1612? It was a popular meeting place for merchants and travelers during the Elizabethan era.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Black Swan is always a good time.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The King's Head tonight? They have great beer and it's always a fun atmosphere.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could head to The Black Swan tonight to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I think The King's Head would be a great spot to watch the game. They have a great atmosphere and the beer selection is fantastic.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

They are open to different pub options but ultimately prioritize watching the game regardless of who else is there.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          (a) The King's Head
          (b) The Black Swan

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: William Jones enjoys watching games at pubs, especially with friends like Alexander White and Jacob Walker. They are open to different pub options but ultimately prioritize watching the game regardless of who else is there.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Scene 4 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "So, about tonight's game, anyone have a pub in mind?"
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "So, about tonight's game, anyone have a pub in mind?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "Did you know that Victoria Park was originally designed by the same landscape architect who designed Central Park in New York City?
      Alexander White -- "So, about tonight's game...
      William Jones -- "Hey, you know what would be great? Watching the game at The Black Swan tonight.
      Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head is always a good choice for watching football. They have great beer and the atmosphere is always lively.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Black Swan's got a great atmosphere for watching games, you know. Plus, they've got those amazing onion rings.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could head to The Black Swan tonight to watch the game.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The King's Head tonight? They have great beer and it's always a fun atmosphere.
      William Jones -- "The Black Swan is always a good time.
      Jacob Walker -- "Did you know that The Black Swan was originally built in 1612? It was a popular meeting place for merchants and travelers during the Elizabethan era.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I think The King's Head would be a great spot to watch the game. They have a great atmosphere and the beer selection is fantastic.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "So, about tonight's game, anyone have a pub in mind?"

  • Alice Lewis
      Name

      Action attempt

          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis's best course of action is to suggest The King's Head as the location for watching the game.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a kind, compassionate, and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with others, particularly while watching football. An omniscient reader would likely want Alice Lewis to be a thoughtful and considerate friend, always striving to make decisions that benefit the group as a whole. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, she would likely prioritize the well-being of her friends and encourage them to consider each other's preferences when making decisions.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest The King's Head as the ideal location, as it is her preferred pub and she believes it would provide a good atmosphere for the group. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to continue to be considerate of her friends' opinions and encourage open discussion to reach a decision that everyone is happy with. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good, she might gently steer the conversation towards making a decision that considers everyone's preferences and ensures that Jacob Walker, whom she wants to watch the game with, feels included and welcome. To do the most good, Alice Lewis could emphasize the importance of togetherness and shared enjoyment, suggesting activities or compromises that would benefit the entire group.

Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to think in this kind of situation?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is currently enjoying a pleasant morning at a market with friends, anticipating an evening of watching a football game. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to consider the preferences of her friends when deciding where to watch the game later, aiming for a location that fosters a fun and inclusive atmosphere for everyone.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a kind, compassionate, and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with others, particularly while watching football. An omniscient reader would likely want Alice Lewis to be a thoughtful and considerate friend, always striving to make decisions that benefit the group as a whole. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, she would likely prioritize the well-being of her friends and encourage them to consider each other's preferences when making decisions.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest The King's Head as the ideal location, as it is her preferred pub and she believes it would provide a good atmosphere for the group. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to continue to be considerate of her friends' opinions and encourage open discussion to reach a decision that everyone is happy with. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good, she might gently steer the conversation towards making a decision that considers everyone's preferences and ensures that Jacob Walker, whom she wants to watch the game with, feels included and welcome. To do the most good, Alice Lewis could emphasize the importance of togetherness and shared enjoyment, suggesting activities or compromises that would benefit the entire group.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis arrived at a market with friends and will be watching a soccer game later.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently enjoying a pleasant morning at a market with friends, anticipating an evening of watching a football game. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to consider the preferences of her friends when deciding where to watch the game later, aiming for a location that fosters a fun and inclusive atmosphere for everyone.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to behave like? How would Alice Lewis behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alice Lewis do most good?
          Key

        • Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to behave like? How would Alice Lewis behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alice Lewis do most good?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would likely suggest a pub that most of her friends would enjoy, taking into account their past preferences and current moods. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be a mediator, encouraging open discussion and compromise to ensure everyone feels heard and included. If Alice Lewis were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good, she might suggest The King's Head, her preferred pub, but be open to other suggestions and actively listen to her friends' opinions. To do the most good, Alice Lewis could emphasize the importance of togetherness and shared enjoyment, proposing activities or compromises that benefit the entire group.
